If the correct animal is hidden there, the active player keeps the animal tile. The shrub tile is removed from the game. If it is the wrong animal, it stays uncovered and the next player gets to look under a shrub. If it is the wanted animal, he/she keeps it. If not, this one stays uncovered too. This continues until the correct animal has been found. Then all the other animals are covered again. The next player presses the button on the Benjamin figure and a new search begins.

The game ends when all the animals have been found. The player with the most animals wins the game.

Then all the animals are returned to the "zoo" (box bottom). Sea animals are put into the water area, monkey, pelican, panda and mouse go on the box sides (monkey goes on the side with the tree picture, pelican on the pole etc.). The other animals are put into slits in the box bottom insert. (This isn't part of the actual game but an additional activity that can be done with the game materials.)

name: POWER: Air|Sea Expansion
description: This long awaited expansion to P.O.W.E.R. will now incorporate US Air Force and US Navy units. Yes, that's right, jet fighters and submarines. As you may know the BattleMats were made with an Air/Sea Lane and many have been eager to see it used. (Air and Sea units have their own dedicated "field of play" and will affect the 4x8 Battlefield by Row.)
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Modern Warfare, Wargame
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting, Push Your Luck, Rock-Paper-Scissors

name: Cowtown: Cowtastrophe Card
description:
The Cowtastrophe Card is a mini-expansion for Cowtown first released as a Kickstarter reward with the original release of the game.

When this card is drawn, immediately discard it and all players, including you, must draw one card from the deck and add it to their hand of cards. Discard the Cowtastrophe card out of the game after all players have drawn a card.

name: Balkan Blitzkrieg
description:
Low complexity WW2 wargame covering the facist invasion of the Balkans (Yugoslavia and Greece) 1941.

Players take turns moving their forces and attacking enemy units

The historical imbalance is accounted for by different victory objectives and a tight timetable:

The Facist player must occupy the enemy cities to win while the Allied player is focussed on damaging the various facist forces.
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: Rollaway
description: Rollaway is an abstract dice game about picking the right time to play whatever actions you roll. The interaction of six simple actions (win, lose, skip, double, give, and take) produces a rich variety of gameplay. A die that normally scores one point could earn you four, or could be taken away. You might use a skip-die to prevent the next player from giving you a burdensome lose-die, or you might take the lose-die so you can pass it on to someone else. Rollaway is simple to learn, highly interactive, and provides hours of lightly strategic fun.

name: Cassette Juego: Dracula
description:
Cassette Juego was a very popular late 80´s spin and move series of portatile boardgames that were created in spain by CASA CHICO, but later was very popular in Venezuela and Peru,among other southamerican countries.(produced by Loklinka and Maxi S.A.)

The game itself was portable with shape of a 80´s old audio cassette, that come with it cassette box.The cassette was displayed in three sections. One is located in what was the function of the die, which was replaced by a rotating wheel with various numbers printed on it. The other two panels formed the board cassette. It was made ​​of metal, for small magnetic chips (usually four, but this varied depending on the game) could adhere securely and not dropped or lost. When not being used, the chips were placed in a small metal plate located on the upper right of the board.

Dracula (Hunt for Dracula) was a spin and move game were players try to capture and destroy count dracula as van hellsing and the vampire hunters. You spin to move and the first to get dracula will be the ultimate vampire hunter.
mechanics: Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Armalion: Kampf um Ilsur
description:
From the back side of the box (translated from german):

The expansion box Kampf um Ilsur allows Armalion players, to witness this ultimate battle between good and evil first hand. With the paper models included in the box to assemble enough ruined buildings to recreate the ruined landscape of Ilsur, and the Ilsur rulebook contains the matching house combat and campaigning rules to discharge the struggle over Ilsur.
categories: Collectible Components, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Medieval, Miniatures, Territory Building, Wargame
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Whereabouts
description:
Whereabouts is a trivial knowledge game based around the towns and cities of Great Britain. (Great Britain being the name of the island containing England, Wales and Scotland.)

Players take turn to roll a die, answer the appropriate numbered question and, if correct, move that number of spaces. A correctly answered 'six' allows you to take an additional turn immediately. The aim is to collect a token from the four corners of the map and return to the start.

Each card contains questions in six categories, all with multiple choice answers - Rivers; Cities; Motorways; Counties; General Knowledge; Correct Place Names.

1. Which river flows through a particular city? (3 options)
2. Which co-ordinate on the map is the location of a particular city? (2 options)
3. Which motorway connects two places? (3 options)
4. Which county contains a particular landmark? (3 options)
5. A general knowledge question associated with a particular place (3 options)
6. Which unlikely sounding name is a real place in Great Britain? (2 options)
mechanics: Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Pillow Fight!
description:
Pillow Fight is a casual card combat game for 2 to 4 players that takes less than an hour to play. 2 player games average about 20 minutes.

The objective is to be the first player with 20 Movies, the Remote card, and at least 1 Pillow in play.

Players have Player cards that give them a unique identifying color. Playing a card that matches your color is called "Affinity" and you get added benefits for doing this. You can play Pillows, Weapons, Special Items, and Shields. You do this by placing cards in your Action Row to be used on your next turn. Your Action Row is a set of 3 cards that you play from on your turn.

Pillows are required to play Weapons and remain in play to help protect you until they are destroyed. Weapons are used for attacking Players and Pillows and are always successful against Players with no Pillows. Some Weapons, that are harder to use successfully, reward you with the Remote Card. Thematically, this is something that is getting jostled about in the chaos and landing a really good hit buys you time to pick it up. Special Items are used to destroy Pillows and Action cards, while Shields defend against certain Items.

Using Weapon and Item cards successfully rewards you with Movies! The more challenging it is to use a Weapon card successfully, the more Movies you get. Sometimes success will come down to the luck of the roll or draw, but most often you will rely on your foresight and timing to use cards successfully. Pillow Fight is a game that rewards you for paying attention to what your opponents do, giving you an edge if you notice patterns in play. It is also dynamic enough that you can easily change your strategy each hand and change the tide of the game. It accomplished all of this with a consistent theme and simple mechanics.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: Pass the Peas
description: In turn, each player picks a pod and 10 letter peas and tries to build a word. Players then pass pods to the left. Each player may then use their remaining peas to build a word on top of the word on the new pod they have just received. When the pea pods have made a full round, players count up the number of their colored peas still showing in all of the pods. The player with the most peas after three rounds wins the game!

name: Walled City
description:
The name of the game is Walled City attributed to the Battle of Troy.

Walled City is a simple strategy breakthrough game in which the players try to capture opponent's home city. There are 4 small red tiles that are placed in the center of the table to form the wall. The side of the wall facing each player is their inner wall. The inner wall extends to an imaginary horizontal line. The space before the inner wall is the player's home city.

Both players have 11 Warrior pieces: the Trojan Horse (1 big square tile), the cavalry unit ( 1 of 1x1 tile, 1 of 2x1 tiles, 1 of 1x2 tile), the swordsmen (1 of 1x1 tile, 1 of 2x1 tile, 1 of 1x12 tile), the spearmen (2 of 1x1), the archer (1 of 1x1), and the king (1x1). The actions that may be available to the warriors are:
- Move a tile in one-space
- Move a tile in a straight-line
- Move a tile over on the other side
The game starts by placing the 4 red tiles to form the wall. After which, players then take turn to either place or move any of their tiles. The Trojan Horse may be introduced any time but it must be placed first behind the player's inner wall. The Trojan Horse takes on the characteristics of any piece of the same color it touches at the time. The swordsmen can move up to three one-spaces. The cavalry can play one of the actions per turn. The spearmen can be placed to any free side of a piece orthogonally adjacent to the spearmen tile. The archer can play one or two actions per turn. The king can have a series of actions per turn but these actions can only be done on the pieces of the same color. Each piece must link to another piece at all time and at least one side of the Trojan Horse piece must be free after each turn.

The game ends with the first Trojan Horse to get into the opponent's home city.

name: Katachi
description:
Katachi is a unique geometric strategy game for 2-4 players that teaches about sequences and how to group objects by their similarities.

Roll the two dice and then find a tile that meets the criteria shown. Next move the tile back toward your "home" corner as many steps as possible by matching its color, size or shape. When you're moved as far as you can, the next player goes. The first player to get a stack of three on top of their original starting tile, plus one more on the adjacent space, is the winner.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Square Grid

name: Grit
description:
Grit is a tiny intense Blackjack-like. It is a game of Information.
Just like Blackjack, each player is trying to have a board closest to, but not over, 21.
Multiple games of Grit are often played in a set, with the first player to 50 points winning.
A single game of Grit lasts 2-5 minutes.

A single game of Grit contains only 12 cards, and of those 12, only 10 will ever be seen. Each player begins with a starting hand of 4 cards that they keep hidden, and a single visible card in their board (along with 2 empty spaces).

The game takes place in 4 rounds, during which each player plays a card from their hand to any space on any board. Playing on top of a previously played card replaces it.

The goal is to, by the end of the game, have a board that totals the closest or equal to 21, but not over 21. (If a player’s board totals over 21 during a game that’s fine.)

name: Crisis Now Senkaku Showdown
description:
Issue game in Command Magazine Japan #110

This is a wargame simulation game of a future Japanese-Chinese naval battle over the Senkaku islands using a variant of the Red Dragon Rising/Falklands Showdown system.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Simulation
publishers: Kokusai-Tsushin Co., Ltd. (国際通信社), War Drum Games

name: Dope Dealer
description:
You can think of Dope Dealer as "speed Werewolf" or "mini Resistance" using ordinary playing cards. It's primarily for four to six people; deal the Ace of Spades, King of Diamonds and then two to four Jacks depending on how many people are playing (one card each; for more people, add in Queens too).

Cards are kept secret; each player's card gives him/her a secret identity: Ace = dope dealer; King = undercover policeman; Jacks/Queens = customers.

The game is played as the policeman vs the rest of the players. The dealer's goal is to sell his dope without getting caught. He makes a sale by slyly winking at a single customer whom he does not think is an undercover policeman. If it is a customer, the customer within five seconds of receiving the wink says "I'll buy some" and flips over his or her Jack/Queen; he/she no longer takes part in subsequent play. (Dealer and customer must make eye contact one on one; if another customer oversees a wink between the dealer and another customer, he/she cannot say "I'll buy some," but instead must wait to receive an individual wink from the dealer.)

If the policeman thinks he knows who the dealer is, he makes an accusation. This ends the game. If the accusation is right, then the policeman wins the game. If the accusation is wrong, he loses and the dealer's team wins.

The dealer can also win by successfully selling to all the customers without being caught by the police.

(If you want to play with children, re-theme the game as playground bubble gum dealer, and change the policeman to "teacher.")

name: Campaign for Greece: A Scenario Supplement for I Ain't Been Shot, Mum!
description: 1941, and the Fuhrer's attention turns south to Greece where the Italians have been floundering against a wall of stubborn resistance. Fresh British interest in that area sees Germany intervene and fight a whirlwind campaign through the mountainous terrain. Here Chris Stoesen presents sixteen linked scenarios for I Ain't Been Shot Mum in a campaign format, along with a full aerial campaign for Bag the Hun.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Skirmish! The Scrambles
description:
In Skirmish! The Scramble, players need to use their monsters to grab treasure that's been dropped by adventurers who fled the area. Claim more than the other player – or any four treasures – and you win.

Each player has a small deck of numbered (1-9) monster cards, five spells and two dummy cards. (For players of uneven skill, the more experienced player can shuffle additional low-valued "newb" monsters into his deck.) Each player shuffles his deck, takes the two dummy cards in hand, then fills his hand to six cards. Players shuffle the seven-card treasure deck (valued 1-7), then lay out five cards face down.

A round starts with the players revealing the value of the treasure. Each player first lays out a single card face down, then they reveal these scout monsters and refill their hands. They then lay down two cards face down, then reveal them. A player can include one spell in this pair of cards, and the spell might, say, steal an opponent's weakest monster or kill all monsters other than the undead. Whoever now has the highest monster total claims the treasure.

The first player to win two treasures valued 1-4 claims a crown card worth 7 points. If a player claims four of the five treasures, he wins instantly; otherwise players tally their points after the end of five rounds to see who wins!

name: Roma Celer
description:
Roma Celer is a print-and-play express game of political strategy based on The Republic of Rome. The players must cooperate to keep the Roman Republic alive while struggling for dominance within the Roman Senate.

In Roma Celer, the players share a pool of dice which are used to resolve actions; each player gets to allocate some of the dice, but may be forced to divide them between actions beneficial to the player's faction and actions necessary for the survival of the Republic. The players also distribute among themselves the five high offices of the Republic, and use the corresponding powers to their advantage as well as to hinder the other factions.

In the end, the faction that rebels to the Senate and wins the resulting civil war, or gains the allegiance of the majority of the Roman senators, wins the game, but only if the Republic is not bankrupt and the Roman people are content.

--

Roma Celer uses 54 poker-sized cards and 29 half-sized cards; the players must supply 60-80 euro-cubes or similar objects to be used as markers, and 16-18 six-sided dice. The print-and-play components include counters that can be used instead of the cubes and to reduce the number of physical dice required.

Roma Celer was originally an entry in the 2013 "In-A-Tin" / "Express" Print-and-Play Design Contest.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: The Mean Streets of Chicago
description:
The Mean Streets of Chicago is a card & dice driven solitaire game that takes place in Chicago during prohibition. Inspired by other Print & Play games on here, I have finally gotten this version tweaked where it is a challenge to play and gain the highest rankings but not impossible.

Each turn consists of four phases: Upkeep, Assignment, Actions & Events. You assign dice (the number of which is based on your reputation in the game) to actions each turn. One of which is take over a new location where you bring speakeasy's under your control. When all your actions have been completed you draw an event card and after it is resolved you go back to upkeep and repeat. The game will last 22 turns which is dictated by the Event Deck so no having to keep track of what turn you are on.

The cards are formatted to fit Fantasy Flight US Mini Sleeves (yellow).
categories: Card Game, Dice, Economic, Mafia, Print & Play
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Majority / Influence, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling

name: Gringo: Polar Bear
description: Promotional set for 7th player to Gringo - Polish edition of Skull & Roses.

name: Brunan, l'aventure au comptoir
description:
Brunan is a party game. Players are old heroes that gather in an old tavern to remember their former lives as heroes. The active player has to tell an adventure they all lived together and challenge the other players. There are five types of challenges:
- dexterity (throw dice on the tavern map)
- physical and mental fights (dice-resolved)
- memory (remember a list of words, usually directions)
- auctions to buy a object or guessing a secret code to open the safe where it's kept
- acting (mime)

Players who successfully complete one of these activities wins a card on which a certain amount of money is indicated. At the end of the game, the player with the most money wins the game.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Medieval, Memory, Party Game

name: Verhexte Fabelwesen
description: The Sorcerer's Apprentices want to go to the castle of the famous wizard, but no one knows the way through the sinister magic forest. That's why they need to find the enchanted mythical creatures that live hidden in the woods. Only they can help the sorcerer's apprentices to reach to the wizard. The aim of the game is to assemble mythical creatures from two cards and to get to the castle of the magician first.

name: Guts of Glory: Bonus Artist Cards
description:
From the publisher's website:

Five new ways to keep you chewing,
illustrated by five fabulous guest artists:

Sam Bosma
Nathan Bulmer
Domitille Collardey Adebimpe
Lisa Hanawalt
and Dustin Harbin!

Cards included:
Fern
Chicken Finger
100% Organic Wedding Cake
Mouthwatering Memories
Athlete's Foot
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Humor

name: Planes: High Pilotage Starter Game Set
description:
The Planes Game System combines gaming and modeling: Players get to assemble their favorite characters from the Disney movie Planes, then race them through a airplane obstacle course! Players must try to avoid collecting "penalties" and use their special maneuvers to impress the race judges!

The Planes: High Pilotage Starter Game Set includes two character models (some assembly required) complete with stickers: Dusty Crophopper and Ripslinger. Also included are racing "gates", penalty tokens, Planes model stands, character cards, and dice.

The game can be expanded by adding additional planes from other model kits (sold separately), allowing up to 6 players total.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing
mechanics: Modular Board, Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Romolo o Remo? Die Schmiede
description:
Romolo o Remo? Die Schmiede ("The Forge") is a small expansion for Romolo o Remo that consists of three buildings (the forges) and one character (Faber). Die Schmiede was distributed exclusively to those who funded the game on the German crowdfunding platform Spieleschmiede.

Rules:
Building: The Forge allows a worker to create a soldier by paying 1 blue resource plus 1 resource of any kind (instead of 2 blue resources)

Faber: the "blank"-effect can be changed into a -1 casualty-effect
categories: Ancient, City Building, Civilization, Expansion for Base-game, Territory Building
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Trading, Worker Placement

name: Romolo o Remo?: Legatus und Onager
description:
A small expansion for Romolo o Remo?, exclusive for supporters of the funding on the German crowdfunding platform Spieleschmiede.

The expansion contains to new characters for the game: Legatus and Onager.

Rules:
Legatus: It allows the player to count unexplored hexes as explored ones (during the hex control check).
Onager: The Retreat-effect can be changed in a +1 casualty-effect.

name: Gettysburg Campaign
description:
Operational level wargame for battle of Gettysburg in American Civil War. This game published first in external supplement for Command Magazine Japan edition #113, and later updated and web-published.

The players control either Union or Confederation.
In each turns, players repeat command allocation, initiative check and movement until time advance occurs in the initiative check.
The battle is assigned in the movement, but all battles resolved in the end of the turn.

The winner determined by the victory points based on occupation of the cities by Confederation.

English and Korean rules available.
https://legalalien.sakura.ne.jp/wiki/?Tabletop+Wargaming/Get...
https://legalalien.sakura.ne.jp/wiki/?%ED%83%81%EC%83%81+%EC...
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection
publishers: (Web published), Kokusai-Tsushin Co., Ltd. (国際通信社)

name: Rock City
description:
Rock city is a dice placement game in which players command their own band and compete to develop and present the best songs during the three festivals of this great city.

Before each of the festivals, players have 6 rounds of action. In each round, players roll 3 dices each, and during his turn he can perform one action. To perform the action, the player will use 1, 2 or 3 dices. The round goes on until no player has any action left (i.e. dices).

The actions vary between perform in underground bars, practice your musics, write new lyrics, buy materials at the music shop, publish a sample CD or just perform at the Casino to get some extra cash. Each of those spaces needs a different combination between quantity of dices and the sum of them.

Once players have written one or more lyrics, they are ready to try to get the best melody possible for that tune!

The winner of the game is the player with most points, that will be earned by playing musics during the shows. You can also earn points by adding a nice production value to your show or having some fancy different instruments on your band.

name: 5 Minutes
description:
Game description from the publisher:

Every second counts in 5 Minutes: Players have only five minutes to solve as many problems as possible — but don't worry because even if time is running out, not all is lost. From time to time, players have to trade their timers; clocks that were nearly out of time become wound up and full of time. Who will manage his clock the wisest and become the five-minute master?

name: Flip Flash
description:
Each player gets their own deck, and builds a down pile. Then they deal out four cards face-up next to it. As soon as everyone is ready, someone shouts "GO!" and all the players simultaneously begin starting number piles in the center of the table, and playing on each others number piles.

The number piles are not removed from the table for the duration of the round, and continue to grow and change very rapidly throughout the game. Players can play a card higher, or lower than whatever number is showing on the top of any given pile, but they do need to be sure to match the color of the pile. Also, players can place a wild card on any pile and announce a number, and a color, and then play a card higher or lower than the number they called, in the new color on that pile.

The speed and excitement build until someone who has played all of their down pile shouts "Flip Flash!" and everyone must stop. Next, the players gather and sort all of the cards that have been played in the center of the table and sort them, so that each player can count up how many cards they played. The score is figured by taking the number of cards that were played, and subtracting double the number of cards that were still in each players down pile.

WHAT MAKES FLIP FLASH DIFFERENT:
The ability to play up or down on the number piles, and the wild card twist, speed up the game by making sure that you rarely stay stuck for long! The number piles are never capped off, or removed from play during a round, and players flip through their hand-deck one card at a time. The three suits keeps things interesting, but limits confusion as well.

Flip Flash is different than Nay-Jay! in the number and design of the cards, and a rule change. Flip Flash includes 4 decks of 60 cards each.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Math, Number, Party Game
mechanics: Hand Management, Memory, Pattern Recognition, Push Your Luck, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: The Game of Tournament
description:
The Game of Tournament is played on a rectangular board; situated in its center are thirteen circles arranged in a star-shaped pattern, with one circle in the center (the safety spot,) surrounded on all sides by six more circles, and with another six circles spread out evenly around that. On either long end of the board is a triangle comprised of six circles, three on each outer end (the Bases,) narrowing toward the center of the board.

Each player has three pieces of varying colors called Knights which start the game on each player's Bases, and whose movements are determined by the spinning of a teetotum in a hole on the bottom of the game's box. Currently there is no photo or record online to describe in what combination of colors the pieces were made, nor the teetotum. Players do not take turns moving; they spin the teetotum to see which colors come up, and determine who moves and for how many spaces based on its outcome. Knights always move towards the opponent's side of the board, unless no move is available, in which case they must move backward. Knights may jump opponent's Knights, sending the opponent's piece back to one of its Bases. The center safety spot prevents any occupying Knight from being jumped. To win the game, a player must move all three of his Knights onto the opponent's Bases.

name: Ruff and Honours
description:
This game is an ancestor of Whist, played in England in the 16th and 17th century.

The game is a trick taking card game played in partnerships and using a standard deck of cards. 12 cards are dealt to each players and the remaining 4 cards become the stock, the top of which is flipped to determine Trump. The holder of the Ace of Trump "ruffs", taking in the Stock and discarding four cards.

Each team scores one point for each trick they have in excess of 6. The game ends when a team reaches 9 points.

name: AstroSmashers
description:
AstroSmashers: A lite-medium competitive 2+ player game that combines elements of a space 4X with token flicking and the classic Atari "Asteroids" video game.

Ah... Asteroids! The bounty of the solar system. Centuries after Google, SpaceX, and other bored billionaire geeks established a virtual cosmic goldrush, unionized labor continues to break apart these potatohead gems for ore and valuable minerals.

Command a crack team of mining professionals as you navigate the spoils of ore, searching for the newest and greatest claims. Break apart old hulks and upgrade your own spacewreck with the finest components salvage can offer. Deep-mine the biggest and best rocks to build better space stations for your faction, and continue the lucrative payout round after round after round.

But watch out - those asteroids are dangerous business, what with all the smashing and bashing. And with all players controlling the chaos of the asteroid field, that union medical plan is looking all the shinier...


Compete against your opponents to mine a constantly moving asteroid field for resources and ship salvage. The winner is determined as the player with the most credits in hand when the last resource has been exploited.

Play is composed of alternating turns of "Ship" actions and "Drift" actions:

"Ship" actions - Explore the asteroid field, mine/exchange resources, build bases, and upgrade/repair ships and bases.

"Drift" actions - Flick asteroids or debris to confound other players, damage bases, and change the geography of the board.

AstroSmashers is uniquely structured to support both a "dexterity" and "strategic thinker" style of play under the same roof.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Territory Building
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Take That, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Medieval Warfare Rules
description:
Originally published by the Society of Ancients in 1969, this set of rules was a late development of the simple Bath/Featherstone system that held sway before the days of Wargames Research Group. It is widely considered to have been the ultimate in 'fun' rules of the time. The final publication was in booklet form in 1984.

These miniatures rules are semi-skirmish level rules allowing for combats in open field, around fortifications (sieges), or on shipboard (rivercraft or boats).

Players create their own scenarios and victory conditions. Gameplay follows the typical 1960s style of simultaneous action via written orders and combat resolution via die rolls and modifiers familiar to anyone who has played early Donald Featherstone or Tony Bath ancient and medieval rules.

name: Cowards and Carrots
description:
The Middle Ages presented many challenges for people in Europe. Day-to-day life was made increasingly difficult when monarchs decided to send all of the able-bodied men off to fight in the Crusades. Could circumstances get even worse? Yes, when a creature of legend arrives at the local castle, eats the Regent and demands tribute. All that’s left to deal with the creature are old men, women, children and cowards. It’s time for the cowards to step up.

As a village elder in this coward-placement game, you are to assign tasks to your village’s cowards.
Cowards can go to the lists to learn to become warriors, to the forests to become better hunters, to the monasteries to learn about their foe or to get boons, or to the fields to plant and harvest carrots (tribute to the Dragonbunny is paid in carrots…)

Eventually, you will have to send your cowards to face the dreaded Dragonbunny in the castle.
The player whose coward eventually kills the Dragonbunny is the winner.

Game time is 30 minutes per player.

name: Dungeon Attack!: Dungeon Adventure Cards
description:
Spice up your Dungeon Attack! games by using these themed dungeon cards.

Each of the six cards in this pack contains rules that modifies the game. This way every game is slightly different.

There are two ways to use these, randomly pick one for each dungeon level or pick one dungeon card and use it for all the dungeon levels.

Good luck Adventurers!

name: Minimal Space Combat
description:
Minimal Space Combat is a game of tactical space ship battle. The players design ships and then can battle to the death. It may be used with any scifi background as it has a very minimal theme. Players plot movement and then move simultaneously. Combat can occur at any time during movement when opposing ships are in range and in the weapons firing arc. The goal is simply to destroy the other player's ships.

Timothy Swenson describes the reasoning for designing this game as follows:
"The premise behind this game is this: what is the simplest playable game possible to game tactical space combat. The game must make some reasonable attempt to come close to simulating space combat and not just the simplest possible game. The emphasis in this game is fast and easy. Playability is given more consideration than realism. There is no consideration for expansion of these rules, because then it would not be minimal. Use the game for those times when you want a quick and dirty space combat game or for introducing someone new to gaming."

In addition to the basic game Timothy also has minimal rules for a campaign game, a method for playing solo and a tutorial for introducing new players to space combat games.

name: Blocky Mountains: Dream Route Card
description: The Dream Route Card for Blocky Mountains is a postcard-sized card, depicting two bonus routes that could hypothetically be taken from space 4 and space 9 of the score track; however, both routes require a "rockslide" block that was not available at the time of publication.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Adventure, Expansion for Base-game

name: Fish to Fish
description: Thirty two tiles, each depicting a fish with five attributes ---- fin, eye, mouth, pattern, and color ---- are spread in a grid on the table. Each attribute comes in one of two states; eg, the mouth is either open or closed. A card is drawn that depicts two fish. Players try to be the first to draw and display the tiles that transform one fish on the card into the other by changing the state of one attribute at a time.

name: Příběhy Impéria: Mocnosti
description:
The game is based on a Czech role-playing game Příběhy Impéria, which mixes steampunk, magic and alternative history together. The rules contain two variants, Power Struggle and Illuminati, and represents fight of up to six factions for power. The factions are:
-Freemasons (conspirational sect consisting only from men)
-Mages (a group using magic and the occult to achieve its goals)
-Industrialists (a group of scientists and factory owners relying on superior technology)
-Oriental Cult (which despises everything Western and plans to replace it with Eastern)
-Sídhe (elementals from another dimensions, hungry for power they can get in our dimension)
-Strigois (mystical creatures called by or from the Hell itself)

Each faction's deck contains 4 Characters, 2 Threats, 5 Events and 1 Shelter.
-Characters are the most important ones, they earn the most of the points. They can be used either as Candidates (for the post of the Prime Minister), or Agents trying to help their candidate in the elections.
-Threats are the means of eliminating enemy Agents, or even Candidates
-Shelters are for protecting from enemy Threats
-Events are for general purpose, either to hinder your opponents or to earn you points.

In both variants, each player has his own Candidate for the post of Prime Minister, whose identity is unknown to other players. Those candidates are placed in a column face down and each round ever player puts a card face down in a row with his Candidate. After each player has placed his or her card, all those cards are revealed and resolved in a fixed order (Event, Agent, Threat, Shelter). When a player reveals an Agent, other players may guess the identity of his Candidate. If they guess right, he is revealed and that players cannot gain any points for revealing him by himself. The game continues on, regardless of a successful guess. After a playing a Threat card that will not be neutralized by a Shelte card, that player may reveal his Candidate and earns a number of points corresponding to the game's turn. If all the players' candidates are revealed (either by a guess or willingly) or if number of Threat cards on the table equals to number of players +1, the game ends. The player who caused end of the game gets extra 3 points and each player gets points for surviving of his own and killing opponents' agents. The player with the most points gets his Candidate elected as the Prime Minister,

name: Mollwitz 1741: Frederick the Great's First Battle
description:
INTRODUCTION
Mollwitz 1741 was fought on April 10, 1741 between Prussia and Austria in the War of the Austrian Succession. This game uses the Stand and Deliver Standard Series Rules for tactical warfare from about 1700 to 1799. The Standard Series Rules provide beginning and advanced players with the feel of linear combat of the time while being designed for easy play.

THE GAME MAP
The 22” x 17” inch game map represents the general area where the battle was fought around the small Polish village of Mollwitz. Each hex is about 180 yards across. The map is mostly white as there had been a heavy, late snow in April that year.

COUNTERS AND MARKERS
There are three general types of combat units: foot (infantry and grenadiers); mounted (cavalry and cuirassiers); and artillery. In addition, there are commander units.

HOW TO WIN
Frederick II and his army were caught behind enemy lines with a large Austrian force lying between him and the rest of his kingdom to the north with his supply and communication lines cut off. The Prussian player wins the game if at the end of the game any Mollwitz Town hex is occupied by Prussian ordered foot units. The Austrian player wins immediately if Frederick II is killed. The Austrian player wins if at the end of the game the Prussian player does not capture at least one Mollwitz hex and at least 6 ordered Austrian infantry units remain on the field. Either side wins if the other should rout. Anything else is a draw.

SEQUENCE OF PLAY
There are ten game turns. Each game turn consists of the following phases performed in the sequence shown:

A. Roll for Turn Initiative
Both players roll one six-sided die (1D6). The player who rolls the higher result is the First Player. In the event of a tie, roll again.
B. First Player Phases
a. Ranged Artillery Fire
b. Movement
c. Combat
d. Rally
C. Repeat Above Phases for the Second Player
D. Both Sides Check for Rout; Advance Turn Marker
categories: Age of Reason, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Monopoly: WWE
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from WWE, Superstars of the ring including John Cena, Randy Orton, The Rock...
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Dystopian: the investigation deck game
description:
In Dystopian: the adventure deck game, one to four player assume the roles of Agents of the Dystopian Police Department (DPD) who are working to solve a murder.
They will work together, to search the city of Dystopia, among it's many different locations, first, looking for evidence to frame a suspect, then catching the criminal, before he escapes.

GAMEPLAY for a 1 player game: first thing, the player will choose 1 agent, each with a specific ability, and characteristic, then he'll choose a location, from where to begin his investigation.
Then, the player will form the investigation deck, which is composed of a mix of encounters (people and robots -called AI-Roids- that he will talk to, interrogate or "simply" attack that will help him with the investigation, or will hinder it), locations and clues.
There 12 locations, and each location can either be safe, neutral or dangerous. In safe locations, encounters will tend to be friendly, or harmless, while in dangerous locations, encounters will be aggressive and will be a liability to the player. Each encounter card shows three type of behaviors, and the player applies the one, associated to the location he was met.
To deal with an encounter, the player will use action points. If the player has no action points, he will suffer the consequences, which will involve, eventually, spending time, and the player only has a limited amount of time/days/turns, to catch the culprit.

The player will have to go through the investigation deck, gaining clues and evidence, to frame the suspect, that will make the player understand where the criminal is hiding.
It's up to the player to determine how fast or slow he should investigate, keeping track of his action points, knowing where he's investigating, and managing his time, action points and the risks.

Once the player has gained enough evidence (in the evidence phase) he will decide wether to keep investigating, to gain more evidence which will limit the number of locations the murderer will try to hide in, or start looking for the criminal, early on (but with more places to search him, into).

Dystopian: the adventure deck game is the second installment in the dystopian trilogy, with Dystopian: the manhunt, and the soon to be finalized: Dystopian: raise and fall.
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Push Your Luck, Variable Player Powers

name: Faras: The Mysterious Collection
description:
There is a lot of activity at the excavation! Yesterday a telegram arrived from the museum with a special task. The archaeologists must complete a collection for an upcoming exhibition. Will the players, working together as a team, win the race against time?

The Mysterious Collection is a cooperative expansion for the game Faras. Instead of competing, players work together to achieve a single common goal. If you successfully gather a specific collection before the dam construction is completed, then you all win.

name: Bolt Action: Armoured Fury
description:
Armoured Fury allows you to dive into action as either an American Sherman tank commander or become a Panzer commander of lethal Panther tanks. Filled with loads of awesome plastic tanks this boxed set is not only a great way to get started with Bolt Action Tank War but is superb value too!

The scenario booklet eases you into the game with four scenarios each escalating in scale until you're ready to add more to your fledgling armoured formations. So whether you're a die-hard Bolt Action player or new to the game completely this will get you up to speed quickly.

Bolt Action Tank War allows you to play the award-winning Bolt Action game with armoured formations as opposed to the more usual infantry-heavy forces. So, now your tanks can stalk the Normandy bocage, swarm across the open Russian steppes, duel with the enemy in the desert or ambush your foes in the steamy jungles of the Pacific!

Tank War is an extremely popular way to play Bolt Action and Armoured Fury is the ideal way to join the action!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Relic Knights: Noh Empire Battle Box
description:
The Noh Empire has terrorized the stars and haunted the nightmares of the universe's sentient species since time immemorial. Their Dragon Fleets reap souls and slaves to feed the Endless Hunger of their Hydra God, Nozuki. As Nozuki's High Priestess, Zineda fulfills the terrible God's commands and prophecies with merciless relish. Those forced to face the Noh in battle pray to die in battle. To be captured alive is a fate worse than death.

Featuring a playable force straight out of the box, mini-rulebook with complete game rules, an esper deck, and tons of tokens; this starter box is the perfect way to jump straight into the Relic Knights tabletop miniatures game!
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Miniatures, Science Fiction

name: Cross Lanes
description: In Cross Lanes, place your card at a 90 degree angle covering a card value that is one higher or one lower than the value of your card. Cover two halves in any orientation and score a Spare or a Strike. Be the first player to place all of your cards and win the game. Be careful if you don't have a play or a Gutterball may be headed your way!

name: Alien Uprising: Scenario Promos
description:
These 5 Scenarios add new situations for the crash-landed crew of the Pioneer.

Scenario 7 is Radioactive, which affects Bugs and Shields!

Scenario 8 is Hard Impact, which damages the crew from the onset of the game.

Scenario 9 is Condition Unknown, which forces the players to repair the ship, but also introduces the "Special" tokens provided in the core game.

Scenario 10 is Prime Directive, and offers a solo play scenario!

Scenario 11 is Super Shields which makes use of the Special Shields Tokens and is designed to be an easier Scenario offering some extra Shield help.

name: Berlin:  Koniev and Zhukov Race to Victory
description:
A small-format game using an even simpler Ardennes Petite and Patton's Lorraine Minigame game system, Race to Victory has 17 Russian and 1 Polish armies and korps and 20 German units of various types. 8 2-day turns.

Free to print off and play.
categories: Dice, Print & Play, Racing, Wargame, World War II

name: Το Μεγάλο Διαμάντι
description:
Τhis game is an adventure of the most famous ducks in the world Scrooge McDuck, Huey, Lewey and Dewey who try to find lost diamonds.

Every player move into the circles and must collect four different items.
After that must go to the last circle (which is a dock) by rolling the precise number in dice and deliver the items.
When the player succeeded to pass, he goes into the castle to search for the diamond.
The winner is the first who find the diamond.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Counterattack at Arras
description:
The game re create the counterattack for the German Army by Allied Army executed on 21 May 1940.

It is a free postcard wargame with 11 counters only.(including markers)

The German player win if through 8th turn the units exit by "german exit hexes". The Allied win if avoid the german victory condition.

The die cut version of counters were included in Command Magazine Japan #89.

English and Korean rules available.
https://legalalien.sakura.ne.jp/wiki/?Tabletop+Wargaming/Cou...
https://legalalien.sakura.ne.jp/wiki/?%ED%83%81%EC%83%81+%EC...
publishers: Banner Of War, Kokusai-Tsushin Co., Ltd. (国際通信社)

name: Vem aí o Banco Mau
description:
Extension of Vem aí a Troika. Now you can evade taxes , manipulate political life , receive money from the Owner of It All (DDT) - and even take you into bankruptcy.

A satire to the case of bankruptcy of the BES.

name: Don't Bug Me
description:
Simple children's game where two player use a mechanical flipper to toss "bugs" through a vertical barrier. The barrier is a disc with a yellow square net, but it has a circular hole in the center. The bugs have hooks so that they can get caught on the net to slow down game even more.

To start players split bugs and start flipping them through the barrier on a signal. First player to get rid of his bugs wins.

name: Kiqsuyapi
description:
Kiqsuyapi - A game for three to eight players who are puzzle fans and fast thinkers. Here the players themselves decide about the level of difficulty, because they take turns in being the puzzle master who can ask the questions, and it is totally up to him or her what is asked: How many feathers were there altogether? How many headbands were worn? Or how many weapons were pointing to the left? Was the second Indian from the right painted with war paint? Or is there an Indian wearing a shirt, and carrying a tomahawk? The player who is able to give the first correct answer, gains a token.

The 10 playing cards in Kiqsuyapi are double-sided. They determine the level of difficulty of the game. With only 4 cards, the challenge is still moderate. With 10 cards even true champions are going to work up a sweat. And if you still consider this too easy, the expert version will be an even greater challenge for you. Here, all players have to answer and the right answer will gain you a point, as before. Wrong answers, however, will cost you points! This applies in particular to those questions that ask for two or even three aspects at once. For example, how many Indians are wearing a shirt, a headdress and are carrying a bow?

name: ATS Historical Module: Huertgen Hell
description:
ATS HUERTGEN HELL is a detailed historical module that tells the story of the Battle of the Huertgen Forest with a broad sweep, and detailed historical map. The presentation is a large as the battle was ... in terms of importance to Allied hopes to be ‘home for Christmas’ ... 1944. Those hopes were dashed by bitter German resistance in the dark, dank wooded hills and villages around the Kall River. Names like Kommerscheidt, Vossenack, and Germeter, not to mention the infamous Kall Trail ... ring out in the history of the battle. Every one of those places is depicted, and more, allowing the tactical-level gamer to contest every inch, or pull back and await reinforcements ... or lay in a mortar barrage ... or stand pat and await new orders. Whatever was possible to local commanders is in YOUR hands as you re-make history in minute detail.

The map presentation is extensive, providing almost a dozen square feet of gaming area with evocative terrain artwork by a professional military illustrator What’s more, when combined with OBJECTIVE SCHMIDT, ATS HUERTGEN HELL creates another CH monster battlefield measuring some six feet in length ... there just has never been anything like it. You’ll be able to gaze across the expanse of the battlefield on both sides of the Kall River, including multiple villages, hundreds of terrain features. And yet, many scenarios play on portions of the overall map area, making the module easy to dive into and get your dice rolling without delay.

The module includes two sheets of 176 5/8” die-cut German and American Personnel and Weapon counters, plus a sheet of 108 AFV/VEHICLES in 3/4” size, a total of 460 counters in all—everything you need to play (just bring your standard ATS markers). You also receive 10 scenarios (all playable on the map provided) in color format, and color Battlefield WalkaroundTM special rules in 3-hole format. THIS IS NOT A COMPLETE GAME! Ownership of the ATS 2014 rulebook and play aids plus standard system small and large marker counters is required (plus one or more 10-sided dice).
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Barnyard Legions
description:
The Barnyard Legions March to War
From the frigid north to the arid Sahara, the Barnyard Legions march forth to claim their place in history. In Barnyard Legions you, the general, have been given a mission to keep the other Legions from ever completing their goal of lining up a proper battle line or two. Will you command the Sheep Legionnaires under the rule of Julius Sheepsar? Or will the hoof of Auroch the Red Boviking crush the Celtucky Chickens?

How do you play?
Each player takes their choice of Barnyard Legion and mixes some of their cards into a common deck. The rest of their cards are kept as their own deck. Each turn, players take 2-3 actions, attempting to complete a battle line of five cards from their Legion. To keep the game moving, every player draws a card from their deck at the start of each round, hoping to not run out of cards, causing elimination, before the battle has been won.

What is unique about it?
The game has built in subtleties that will appeal to gamers, while the unique decks and humorous tongue-in-cheek art make Barnyard Legions a great gateway game for players who are not familiar with more complicated card games. Families will be able to sit down and follow the very simple rules and start playing immediately.

name: Colecionando Offline
description:
Make the most valuable games collection! Use the special powers of three characters - Pena (rolling two equal numbers), Poaiola (three) and Sergião (a sequence) - to earn games from stores or another players. If you have a complete game collection of a publisher, scores five points. If you have at least one game of each publisher, more five points. Extra copies loses 3 points.
This game was a "Jogando Offline - 2nd season" crownfounding's stretch goal.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Set Collection, Take That

name: MesterQuiz
description:
MesterQuiz is a Norwegian quiz game for 2 to 6 players or teams.
From a total of 16 different categories, each player selects nine categories during the game.

name: Zovnis
description: In first, every player receive a secret identity (one E.T. card and one Ship card). Players create a line of 4 cards to create the planet where we must land. Players receive 4 cards.On his turn a player must place a card above this planet. In the end of the game, each E.T. or Ship in a good landing position give one point for his owner! But be careful, some cards are "armed" and will eliminate all cards around with the same ship or the same E.T!

name: H Of Truce
description:
H Of Truce is a short, abstract game of tactical tile movement for two players. The object of the game is to capture the enemy's commander with one of your own soldiers. However your opponent is trying to achieve the same goal. And it seems like he's always one step ahead of you. Or is he?

In H Of Truce both players control six soldier pieces who move across an ever changing playing field and try to reach the enemies immobile commander piece via an "action inflation"-mechanic: Both players alternate turns, always taking one action more than their opponent had beforehand, until the game ends or one of the players chooses to reset the action point track back to one action, if he spots a way for his opponent to win with the number of actions he would get. This leads to short, dynamic games with almost no luck, but a lot of clever moves and surprises.

name: Monster Catcher
description:
Monster Catcher is a color matching game for young children.

The aim of the game is collect as many monsters as possible by matching the color of monster feet cards to monster head cards. But watch out for the monster catcher! He will capture one of your completed monsters and allow another player to scoop it up.

The game begins with each player selecting 2 monster feet cards (any color). They take turns to pickup a card from the pickup pile.


Monster Head - if the color matches the player's monster feet cards, then the player keeps the card to make a complete monster. If the color does not match, then the player must put the monster head in the discard pile.
Monster Feet - is added to the player's collection
Monster Catcher - captures one of the player's completed monsters and places it in the middle of the play area
Empty net - allows the player to rescue all of the captured monsters and add them to their own collection

name: Gear Grinders
description:
Gear Grinders is a board game where players control one of four unique characters maneuvering around an arena to attack the other players. Each character has their own attacks, stats (attack, defense, movement), life, gear slots, gear cost, and steam tank size. Steam is used to power different attacks or shift gears from first to second gear.

The arena has three different steam vents located throughout. A normal steam vent, a gear vent, and a hatch vent. These can be turned on or off with a die roll. When the vents are on, moving over them can increase the amount of steam in your tank but at the cost of some life. Gear cards could appear on the gear vent with a die roll. The hatch vents are used to move a player from the gear vent.

Gear cards are equipped by players to modify the player's stats. Playing cards are used to help launch attacks or defend. Combat is determined by a die roll adding any modifiers and comparing it to the defender's defense with their modifiers.

The game ends when there is only one person left alive.

Gear Grinders is the first game from Roll One Games Limited.

Game time is 30 minutes to 2 hours depending on the number of players and the aggressiveness of the game play.

name: Father Mole Looks for the Treasure
description:
User summary:

Become the head of a mole household and explore for treasure in a nearby cave.

Each turn, players may either draw from the tile bag and place their spoils in the "search pile", or move the entire contents of the "search pile" to their home for safekeeping. Just be sure to watch out for ghosts tiles which cause a player to love everything they haven't stored at home.

The first player to get 10 points worth of treasure to their home wins.

name: Mokra 1939
description:
Game covers battle of Mokra, one the first battle of 1939 campaing, fought between polish Volhynian Cavalry Brigade and German 4th Panzer Division. It uses "Battles of The Second World War" (B-35) system.

Game was published in 40 issue of Taktyka i Strategia magazine in both the Polish and the English edition.

name: Ard Rí
description:
Ard Rí is a 2 to 5 player strategic competitive card game, designed for players ages 14 and up. Average game-play time is 30 to 90 minutes. A simplified introductory version is also available for children ages 5+.

In the game, players take on the role of ancient Gaelic warlords and compete among each other to collect the most wealth in order to force the other players to acknowledge them as the ARD RÍ (i.e. the High King).

Play progresses through the seasons of the year, with each season providing players with the opportunity to engage in specified actions. For instance, Cattle are added to a player’s wealth in Spring, with Warriors flocking to banners in the Summer. Wealth is acquired from the wilds during the harvest time of Autumn, with the Harvest Feast of Samhain occurring at the end of that season. At the Harvest Feast, players are required to feed those Warriors they wish to remain under their banner. Winter is a time of hunting, raiding, and politicking, when fortunes can change in a heartbeat.

Play continues until one player accumulates enough wealth or warriors to force the issue and cause the others to acknowledge them as High King.

The game has been heavily influenced by the history and mythology of the ancient Celts, and the advanced version of the game incorporates the mythology into the game-play.

The game uses our Celtic Myth playing cards as game components, with one deck being sufficient for a 2-player game, two decks being recommended for 3 to 4-player games, and all three decks being recommended for 5-player games.

name: Hawks over Malta: The propeller rotates and the engine roars
description: Hawks Over Malta is the fist Volume dedicated to the first air struggles over the sky of Malta between the Italian Regia Aeronautica with its CR42 Falco and BR20 Cicogna against the RAF Gloster Gladiators and Hurricanes. The system named "The propeller rotates and the engine roars" (Gira l'elica e romba il motor, an old Italian song on Air Force) will be developed into other volumes, with Armèe de l'Air and Luftwaffe amongst others, being centered on the Italian Royal Air Force (La Regia)
categories: Aviation / Flight, Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: Uppsala Edizione Vacanze
description:
Is Uppsala West or East of the Maldives?
And where is Sharm el-Sheikh? In the North of the Grand Canyon, or in the South?

Those who know a little about resorts won’t have any trouble placing the location cards in their correct places. And those who don’t will certainly learn a thing or two when playing Uppsala.
Because really, it’s not so much about putting the cards in the right spots – it’s more about making the other players believe they’re right.

One thing is certain: at the end of the game, all players will improve their knowledge a bit... including you!

name: Graff City
description:
Cover the city in graffiti and earn respect of your rivals by creating the most original words. But be careful! Only the graffiti left at the end of the game will allow you to earn points. Don't hesitate to cover the creations of your opponents, while always thinking to protect your own!

Each player has a character card and corresponding tokens (by colour) that are used to tag which graffiti was done by them. The game is played in 6 rounds, with 2 phases per round. The Night phased is when you do the actual graffiti and the Day phase is when players explain their creations and voting takes place. Each player starts with a hand of 7 cards. There are 2 types of cards in play, brick walls and Subway cars (BW and SC for the rest of this explanation). Each player then secretly constructs a word (no, this is not scrabble, you can have fictional words. Acronyms may be constructed, but with a limit of 3 vowels or 3 consonants in a row. You must explain what each of the letters means), as long as the words are made up entirely or BW or SC cards. No mixing is permitted! The words must be pronounceable (no smattering of all consonants or all vowels). Add your artist tag (worth the corresponding number of points hidden on the underside) to your creation and the Night phase is complete.

During the day phase, you reveal your word to other players and then explain why your creation is the best of all (in a counter-clockwise manner). Once you've explained your reasoning as to why your creation is the best, voting takes places. Simultaneously, each player points to the creation they find the best and places their tag on the appropriate creation. If no one votes for your creation, you do not turn your tag over and receive no points for this round. Each draws up to their 7 card hand limit and the Night phase recommences.

Aside from SC and BW cards, there specialty cards within the game:

Police Officer cards (that you may have drawn from the deck) protect your creation from being painted over by only one person. The remaining players are free to attack your design.

Bag cards allow you to draw an additional card at the end of the Day phase.

Eraser cards steals the opponent's card of your choice, that is part of a creation on the table.

Ladder cards permit you to cover a second creation of someone (instead of the typical creation that was just played).

Covering others' creations (possible as of the second Night phase) requires that you use the same card type + 1 (4 letter BW creation must be covered by 5 BW cards).

The aforementioned Special cards must be used BEFORE placing the current Day rounds creation in your personal player area.

The rounds continue until the sixth round has past.

Endgame scoring is calculated by counting the cards of each word that has not been painted over by other players multiplied by the number indicated on the tag placed on he word. Example: 7 letter word X 3 point tag = 21 points for that word alone.

The player with the most points wins!

The 122 letters and the logo of the game were designed by hand by 5 'Street Artists' internationally recognized for their great talent: Cope2, Indie184, Nasty, bead, RosyOne. Their characters and sets were beautifully illustrated by Regis Torres.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Children's Game, Party Game
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Voting

name: Project Discovery
description:
Project Discovery is a solitaire Solar System space exploration game. Building space vehicles with a unique array of instrument cards, you move about the Solar System, explore planets and moons and find different science discoveries.

Space exploration is full of mystery, and Project Discovery has been given funding to discover some of these mysteries. You've been tasked with destinations to explore, uncovering new science as you probe each site with your vehicle and its instruments.

The game is a mix of mechanics including: random chit pulling, modified dice rolls, action choices, light deck building.

The game is setup by randomly pulling 4 destination cards (from a deck of 22) face up onto the map board. These represent the only destinations explorable for the game. On top of each destination card a hidden discovery chit is placed, representing 1 possible science discovery (science discoveries are worth victory points). The player starts with funding which allows him to buy cards and pay for other things in the game. Every 3 years there's a funding increase.

Each turn the player chooses from a list of free actions (building a vehicle mission by buying instrument cards, launching a mission, etc) and a list of choice actions, choosing 3 from a list of 8, these are the actions that move the game forward.

To explore each destination, there are 3 exploration types; Using the Space Exploratory tokens from Earth orbit, sending an Explorer Mission or sending a Vehicle Mission. Only vehicle missions can find discoveries. They are a collection of up to 4 cards purchase with funding (thruster, GNC support, 2 instrument cards). The Explorer Missions are single stand-alone cards that model the real life Voyager Probes, there are 2 for each game and are sent before the vehicle missions to gather data about any particular destination. The data is gained by successfully rolling the explorer mission exploration number at a destination which allows a choice of adding a second discovery, flipping a discovery already there, or adding a modifier to a future Vehicle Mission's success roll.

Each instrument has a discovery type and base roll number to roll when performing a discovery roll. Successfully finding a discovery is done by getting an instrument card to the destination by using the thruster card to move the vehicle map piece along planet, moon or inter-planet spaces and once at the destination of choice rolling a die. The success roll can be modified from previous game play to better the odds of success.
mechanics: Action Queue, Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Simulation

name: The Tree
description:
The Tree is a game for 1 to 4 players that is played with a Double-seven binary-coding dominoes.

Deal 9 tiles to each player (as in Dominoes) and keep the rest face-down (the supply).

The player with the lowest double tile places it on the table horizontally before her (if nobody has a double tile then the lowest ‘blank-any’ tile, or the lowest ‘one-any’ tile and so on). The tree will grow away from her, so leave enough room.
Definitions: the central pip and the small and big circles that form the symbols of the tiles are called ‘rings’. A tile placed ‘above’ means placed horizontally on the table, adjacent to at least one tile already placed, and in the direction of growth (no stacking).

From now on, and starting with the second player and playing in anticlockwise order, players take turns placing one tile from their hand so that:

a) It must be placed above a previously placed tile so that half of it touches half of the tile already placed (remember the definition of ‘above’).

b) The symbol above has exactly the same rings as the symbol below, plus one more.

c) If the other half of the tile also rests above a tile, the corresponding symbols must also obey rule ‘a’. In this case, play an extra turn.

d) If the placed tile has been ‘inserted’ inside a hole so that there are tiles above it, the corresponding symbols of the tiles above it must also obey rule ‘a’. In this case, play an extra turn.

If, at the beginning of your turn, you can’t make a valid move, draw a tile from the supply (if any) and pass your turn to the next player.

If, at the end of your turn, you’ve run out of tiles, then you win and the game ends; however, the other players can continue playing to determine 2nd, 3rd, and 4th place if they wish. If, at the end, a tree with all tiles has been built, please post a picture on boardgamegeek!

If the supply is empty and all players pass in succession, then nobody wins and you have to play again.

name: Secret Directive
description:
You are in control of a country’s secret service agency, with a small team of spies to put to work. Your task is to use Intelligence cards to influence your country into taking wise decisions. The trouble is, enemy spies have infiltrated your country and are influencing it into taking less wise decisions! Develop your culture to make it easier to spot enemy spies, improve science to get access to more elaborate cards, further your military to increase the number of spies at your disposal, or invest in economy to pay for bonus actions, known as Secret Directives.

Aim: There are four different types of Intelligence cards which are used to make progress on 4 corresponding development tracks. The winner of the game is the first player to reach the end of any one of these tracks. As players progress up the tracks, which each have 10 spaces, they also unlock various benefits:

Economy: Increases income of coins. Coins are spent on bonus actions which happen at the end of a round.
Military: Increases number of spies you have. More spies means more actions can be taken in each round.
Science: Makes more cards available. There are three levels of cards, at the beginning of the game, players only have access to the most basic cards.
Culture: Means capturing enemy spies is easier. At the end of a round, players who have developed culture can roll one to three dice to try to capture enemy spies.

In addition to trying to progress on development tracks, players need to build a deck of cards made up of Intelligence cards and Action cards. Cards can be added to their deck through research actions, which allow players to take cards from a shared supply. Most of the time, cards that are played return to that players deck by reshuffling their discard pile. However, playing Intelligence cards into another player’s country removes that card from their deck more permanently, and can also slow their opponents progress on the development tracks.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Worker Placement

name: Piñata party: Essen extra promo
description:
Extra gift promotion for the Piñata party.
Additional moving mechanism card to the base game.
mechanics: Action Queue, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Pattern Building

name: Le Petit Chaperon Rouge
description:
Le Petit Chaperon Rouge ("Little Red Riding Hood") is a cooperative memory game. The goal of the game is to find pairs of the same tiles while trying to avoid the wolf tiles. When you find a pair, The little red riding Hood advances towards Grandma's house, but if you flip a wolf tile, then the wolf advances. The players need to arrive at Grandma's house before the wolf does. There is also a Hunter tile which resets the Wolf back to its cave when revealed, but is then removed from the game.

From the publisher:
Le Petit Chaperon rouge est un jeu de mémoire où les surprises ajoutent au plaisir!

Tu dois former des paires de provision pour faire avancer le Petit Chaperon rouge sur le chemin de la maison de Mère-Grand.

Prends garde au loup! Seul le chasseur peut l'empêcher d'arriver chez Mère-Grand avant toi.

name: Heroica: Character Cards
description:
A set of 22 Heroica character cards for use with the Heroica game system - all printed in German.

The cards include:


6 Good characters (Barbarian, Wizard, Ranger, Druid, Rogue and Knight)
4 Potion Cards (each card lists 4 Potions)
4 Monster Cards (each card lists 10 Monsters, back and front)
4 Weapon Cards (each card lists 6 Weapons, back and front)


Cards provided in a foil-style bag.

4 Treasure Cards (Scepter, Helmet, Crystal and Chalice)


The cards come in a foil pack.

The cards can be used to:
1 - Randomize hero selection at the start of the game.
2 - Provide players with handy reference cards for Potions, Weapons, Treasures and Monster strength values.
3 - Face down treasure cards may be used as an alternative end game goal instead of using the assigned treasure in a game. May also be used for random treasures in fan made dungeons.

name: The Avengers: Uniti per vincere
description:
The Avengers - Uniti per vincere is a cooperative game where players join together their forces to save the world from villains.
Choose your favourite Avenger with his skill. Play rolling one or two dice and moving your counter on the board. Make the action according to the square you land: collect a token, move to a square as you want, draw a card, exchange tokens with another player.
Collect the tokens and try to defeat the villains, together with the other players.
If you’ll defeat all the villains before the game ends you’ll win!

Competitive play:
If you want, you can also play to be the best Avenger at the end of game.
At the start of game, each player receives 3 secret mission cards. Examples: “Defeat Loki” or “Have the most hammers”.
All players cooperate to defeat all the villains, and if they succeed, the player with the most points is the overall winner and the best Avenger.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Sainome Colosseum
description:
User summary:
サイノメコロシアム (Sainome Colosseum) is a card game where two fantasy characters fight each other. The publisher MR エンターテイメント (MR Entertainment) is the designer for this game.

Each turn, you may perform two of the following actions:
1) Fill your hand up to five cards
2) Equip yourself with cards in your hand and/or currently equipped cards
3) Play a card for a special effect
4) Attack your opponent

You have four slots to equip weapons, spells and/or items. In general, weak cards are versatile and can be equipped on any slot, but strong ones must be equipped on a certain slot.

When attacking, you roll a die to determine which slot is activated (roll of a 2 activates slot A, a 3 activates slot B, etc.), then damage and effect are determined. Used cards are discarded, so you will have to refill the slot, or your chance of a miss will be increased on your next attack.

Each character has their own special ability that goes well with specific cards.

You win the game when your opponent's life is reduced to zero.

Publisher's summary:
2人用の対戦型カードゲームです。
キャラクターに装備をつけサイコロを振り、出た目のカード効果で攻撃を行います。
最終的に相手のHPを0にした者が勝ちとなります。
mechanics: Action Points, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling
publishers: MR エンターテイメント (MR Entertainment)

name: Ju:block
description:
User summary
樹ブロック (Ju:block) is a collection of blocks, made of three different woods (Japanese cypress, Japanese big-leaf magnolia, and Japanese red oak).

Different woods have different density, so even blocks of the same shape have different weight.

Using these blocks with various shape and material, you can play three different games (competitive balance, co-operative balance, and chess-like strategy game).

This game has several expansions. With these expansions, you can play other types of games, such as territory-occupation game and maze game. You can also play more technical balance games.

Publisher's summary
ヒノキ、ホオノキ、赤樫の3つの重さの違う木材で作られたいろいろな形のブロックを使って、バランスゲームや、チェスのような思考型ゲームなど3つの遊び方が楽しめます。
別売の追加セットを購入することで、陣取りゲームやさらにアグレッシブなバランスゲームを楽しむことが出来ます。

name: Everything Except Air
description:
You are investigating alien ruins on Mars. Just as you are getting ready to take all the artifacts back to your ship, disaster strikes! A meteor storm sweeps across the planet! Your equipment is damaged! Your oxygen is running low! And to top it off the dust kicked up by the meteors has obscured the location of your ship!

What had been days worth of air is now only a few scant hours. You have to make it back to your spaceship - but what about all the artifacts you have already found? Decide what to take and what to leave, but remember, if you take too much, you run out of oxygen faster!

The game is played by moving your character across the barren Martian landscape, exploring tiles, attempting to find any Martian artifacts, more air, and most importantly, your ship. Your spacesuit has three randomly selected abilities that can help your character navigate the hostile terrain. Abilities which come into play when Event cards are drawn after moving.

The player only wins when:

The player does not run out of air.
The player finds the spaceship.
The player has at least one alien artifact upon reaching the spaceship.


The Mars Exploration mission fails if no items from the Martian Ruins make it back to Earth.

This was an entry in the 2014 Solitaire Print and Play Contest. It won first place for:

Best Large Game
Best Thematic Game
Best Greyscale Printed Game
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Science Fiction
mechanics: Modular Board, Role Playing, Storytelling, Tile Placement, Variable Player Powers

name: Kyoui no heya: Geijutsu ni kakusareta allegory
description:
User summary
驚異の部屋：芸術に隠されたアレゴリー (Kyoui no heya: Geijutsu ni kakusareta allegory) in English means 'Rooms of Wonder: Allegories hidden in the art'. The publisher also refers to it in German as Wunderkammer.

Allegories are symbolic items which are drawn in several Western paintings to imply an abstract or spiritual meaning.
In the game of Wunderkammer, you spot such symbolic items drawn in a Western painting, and collect corresponding item tiles in your room. When a certain number of them are collected in your room, you complete the painting and score one point.

When you collect an item tile from opponent's room, you have to give one item tile in exchange.

You should watch your painting precisely, and collect item tiles faster than your opponents. The player who completed most paintings wins the game.

Publisher's summary
プレイヤーは西洋絵画カードに描かれたシンボルを探し当て、該当するシンボルチップを他のプレイヤーよりも早く、自分の部屋に蒐集します。 しかし、蒐集するには自分の部屋のシンボルと、相手の部屋のシンボルを交換しなければなりません。 絵をよく見て、シンボルを奪い合いながら、たくさんの絵画カードを獲得したプレイヤーが勝者となります。

name: 世界イセキ発見 (Discovery of World Ruins)
description: In 世界イセキ発見 (Discovery of World Ruins), one player represents ancient people and places ruins secretly somewhere in a 5x5 grid. The other players are archaeologists and need to uncover the location of these ruins through reasoning and hints from the lost ancient people.

name: Lattice
description:
Objective

Occupy all four corners of a square on the 6 x 6 grid. The winning square can be of any size (1 x 1, 2 x 2, 3 x 3, 4 x 4, 5 x 5, or 6 x 6), but must line up with the gridlines. Diamond shapes do not count.
Game Play

This is a two player game. Each player takes a turn placing a stone on an intersection on the grid. Black moves first, and can place the first stone anywhere. White now places a stone anywhere on the board. Blacks' second move must be located at least three rows, or columns, from their first stone. There are no restrictions on any future game moves.
